Document ?_tstart and ?_tend in Kibana

[Preview](https://elasticsearch_bk_114965.docs-preview.app.elstc.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/master/esql-kibana.html#esql-kibana-time-filter)

Notes for reviewers:
* Not sold on the subheadings 🤔 
* Initially I had "auto-incrementing time buckets" as a last subsection (separated out instead of folded under the custom section); I can redo it that way if we want to highlight `BUCKET`s.

Fix for [this issue](https://github.com/elastic/search-docs-team/issues/153)

Please make all necessary code changes to complete this task.

{"type":"user","message":{"role":"user","content":[{"tool_use_id":"toolu_01LYAgb6aq3YL33bM1WoFTrS","type":"tool_result","content":"     1→[[esql-kibana]]
     2→=== Using {esql} in {kib}
     3→
     4→++++
     5→<titleabbrev>Using {esql} in {kib}</titleabbrev>
     6→++++
     7→
     8→You can use {esql} in {kib} to query and aggregate your data, create
     9→visualizations, and set up alerts.
    10→
    11→This guide shows you how to use {esql} in Kibana. To follow along with the
    12→queries, load the "Sample web logs" sample data set by clicking *Try sample
    13→data* from the {kib} Home, selecting *Other sample data sets*, and clicking *Add
    14→data* on the *Sample web logs* card.
    15→
    16→[discrete]
    17→[[esql-kibana-enable]]
    18→=== Enable or disable {esql}
    19→
    20→{esql} is enabled by default in {kib}. It can be
    21→disabled using the `enableESQL` setting from the
    22→{kibana-ref}/advanced-options.html[Advanced Settings].
    23→
    24→This will hide the {esql} user interface from various applications.
    25→However, users will be able to access existing {esql} artifacts like saved searches and visualizations.
    26→
    27→[discrete]
    28→[[esql-kibana-get-started]]
    29→=== Get started with {esql}
    30→
    31→// tag::esql-mode[]
    32→To get started with {esql} in Discover, open the main menu and select
    33→*Discover*. Next, from the Data views menu, select *Language: ES|QL*.
    34→
    35→image::images/esql/esql-data-view-menu.png[align="center",width=33%]
    36→// end::esql-mode[]
    37→
    38→[discrete]
    39→[[esql-kibana-query-bar]]
    40→=== The query bar
    41→
    42→After switching to {esql} mode, the query bar shows a sample query. For example:
    43→
    44→[source,esql]
    45→----
    46→from kibana_sample_data_logs | limit 10
    47→----
    48→
    49→Every query starts with a <<esql-commands,source command>>. In this query, the
    50→source command is <<esql-from>>. `FROM` retrieves data from data streams, indices, or
    51→aliases. In this example, the data is retrieved from `kibana_sample_data_logs`.
    52→
    53→A source command can be followed by one or more <<esql-commands,processing
    54→commands>>. In this query, the processing command is <<esql-limit>>. `LIMIT`
    55→limits the number of rows that are retrieved.
    56→
    57→TIP: Click the help icon (image:images/esql/esql-icon-help.svg[Static,20]) to open the
    58→in-product reference documentation for all commands and functions.
    59→
    60→// tag::autocomplete[]
    61→To make it easier to write queries, auto-complete offers suggestions with
    62→possible commands and functions:
    63→
    64→image::images/esql/esql-kibana-auto-complete.png[align="center"]
    65→// end::autocomplete[]
    66→
    67→[NOTE]
    68→====
    69→{esql} keywords are case-insensitive. The following query is identical to the
    70→previous one:
    71→
    72→[source,esql]
    73→----
    74→FROM kibana_sample_data_logs | LIMIT 10
    75→----
    76→====
    77→
    78→[discrete]
    79→==== Expand the query bar
    80→
    81→For readability, you can put each processing command on a new line. The
    82→following query is identical to the previous one:
    83→
    84→[source,esql]
    85→----
    86→FROM kibana_sample_data_logs
    87→| LIMIT 10
    88→----
    89→
    90→// tag::compact[]
    91→To make it easier to write multi-line queries, click the double-headed arrow
    92→button (image:images/esql/esql-icon-expand-query-bar.svg[]) to expand the query
    93→bar:
    94→
    95→image::images/esql/esql-expanded-query-bar.png[align="center"]
    96→
    97→To return to a compact query bar, click the minimize editor button
    98→(image:images/esql/esql-icon-minimize-query-bar.svg[]).
    99→// end::compact[]
   100→
   101→[discrete]
   102→==== Warnings
   103→
   104→A query may result in warnings, for example when querying an unsupported field
   105→type. When that happens, a warning symbol is shown in the query bar. To see the
   106→detailed warning, expand the query bar, and click *warnings*.
   107→
   108→[discrete]
   109→[[esql-kibana-query-history]]
   110→==== Query history
   111→
   112→You can reuse your recent {esql} queries in the query bar.
   113→In the query bar click *Show recent queries*:
   114→
   115→image::images/esql/esql-discover-show-recent-query.png[align="center",size="50%"]
   116→
   117→You can then scroll through your recent queries:
   118→
   119→image::images/esql/esql-discover-query-history.png[align="center",size="50%"]
   120→
   121→[discrete]
   122→[[esql-kibana-results-table]]
   123→=== The results table
   124→
   125→For the example query, the results table shows 10 rows. Omitting the `LIMIT`
   126→command, the results table defaults to up to 1000 rows. Using `LIMIT`, you can
   127→increase the limit to up to 10,000 rows.
   128→
   129→NOTE: the 10,000 row limit only applies to the number of rows that are retrieved
   130→by the query and displayed in Discover. Any query or aggregation runs on the
   131→full data set.
   132→
   133→Each row shows two columns for the example query: a column with the `@timestamp`
   134→field and a column with the full document. To display specific fields from the
   135→documents, use the <<esql-keep>> command:
   136→
   137→[source,esql]
   138→----
   139→FROM kibana_sample_data_logs
   140→| KEEP @timestamp, bytes, geo.dest
   141→----
   142→
   143→To display all fields as separate columns, use `KEEP *`:
   144→
   145→[source,esql]
   146→----
   147→FROM kibana_sample_data_logs
   148→| KEEP *
   149→----
   150→
   151→NOTE: The maximum number of columns in Discover is 50. If a query returns more
   152→than 50 columns, Discover only shows the first 50.
   153→
   154→[discrete]
   155→==== Sorting
   156→
   157→To sort on one of the columns, click the column name you want to sort on and
   158→select the sort order. Note that this performs client-side sorting. It only
   159→sorts the rows that were retrieved by the query, which may not be the full
   160→dataset because of the (implicit) limit. To sort the full data set, use the
   161→<<esql-sort>> command:
   162→
   163→[source,esql]
   164→----
   165→FROM kibana_sample_data_logs
   166→| KEEP @timestamp, bytes, geo.dest
   167→| SORT bytes DESC
   168→----
   169→
   170→[discrete]
   171→[[esql-kibana-time-filter]]
   172→=== Time filtering
   173→
   174→To display data within a specified time range, use the
   175→{kibana-ref}/set-time-filter.html[time filter]. The time filter is only enabled
   176→when the indices you're querying have a field called `@timestamp`.
   177→
   178→If your indices do not have a timestamp field called `@timestamp`, you can limit
   179→the time range using the <<esql-where>> command and the <<esql-now>> function.
   180→For example, if the timestamp field is called `timestamp`, to query the last 15
   181→minutes of data:
   182→[source,esql]
   183→----
   184→FROM kibana_sample_data_logs
   185→| WHERE timestamp > NOW() - 15minutes
   186→----
   187→
   188→[discrete]
   189→[[esql-kibana-visualizations]]
   190→=== Analyze and visualize data
   191→
   192→Between the query bar and the results table, Discover shows a date histogram
   193→visualization. If the indices you're querying do not contain a `@timestamp`
   194→field, the histogram is not shown.
   195→
   196→The visualization adapts to the query. A query's nature determines the type of
   197→visualization. For example, this query aggregates the total number of bytes per
   198→destination country:
   199→
   200→[source,esql]
   201→----
   202→FROM kibana_sample_data_logs
   203→| STATS total_bytes = SUM(bytes) BY geo.dest
   204→| SORT total_bytes DESC
   205→| LIMIT 3
   206→----
   207→
   208→The resulting visualization is a bar chart showing the top 3 countries:
   209→
   210→image::images/esql/esql-kibana-bar-chart.png[align="center"]
   211→
   212→To make changes to the visualization, like changing the visualization type, axes and colors, click the
   213→pencil button (image:images/esql/esql-icon-edit-visualization.svg[]). This opens
   214→an in-line editor:
   215→
   216→image::images/esql/esql-kibana-in-line-editor.png[align="center",width=66%]
   217→
   218→You can save the visualization to a new or existing dashboard by clicking the
   219→save button (image:images/esql/esql-icon-save-visualization.svg[]). Once saved
   220→to a dashboard, you'll be taken to the Dashboards page. You can continue to 
   221→make changes to the visualization. Click the
   222→options button in the top-right (image:images/esql/esql-icon-options.svg[]) and
   223→select *Edit ESQL visualization* to open the in-line editor:
   224→
   225→image::images/esql/esql-kibana-edit-on-dashboard.png[align="center",width=66%]
   226→
   227→[discrete]
   228→[[esql-kibana-dashboard-panel]]
   229→==== Add a panel to a dashboard
   230→
   231→You can use {esql} queries to create panels on your dashboards.
   232→To add a panel to a dashboard, under *Dashboards*, click the *Add panel* button and select {esql}.
   233→
   234→image::images/esql/esql-dashboard-panel.png[align="center",width=50%]
   235→
   236→Check the {esql} query by clicking the Panel filters button (image:images/esql/dashboard_panel_filter_button.png[Panel filters button on panel header]):
   237→
   238→image::images/esql/esql-dashboard-panel-query.png[align="center",width=50%]
   239→
   240→You can also edit the {esql} visualization from here.
   241→Click the options button in the top-right (image:images/esql/esql-icon-options.svg[]) and
   242→select *Edit ESQL visualization* to open the in-line editor.
   243→
   244→image::images/esql/esql-dashboard-panel-edit-visualization.png[align="center",width=50%]
   245→
   246→[discrete]
   247→[[esql-kibana-enrich]]
   248→=== Create an enrich policy
   249→
   250→The {esql} <<esql-enrich>> command enables you to <<esql-enrich-data,enrich>>
   251→your query dataset with fields from another dataset. Before you can use
   252→`ENRICH`, you need to <<esql-set-up-enrich-policy,create and execute an enrich
   253→policy>>. If a policy exists, it will be suggested by auto-complete. If not,
   254→click *Click to create* to create one.
   255→
   256→image::images/esql/esql-kibana-enrich-autocomplete.png[align="center"]
   257→
   258→Next, you can enter a policy name, the policy type, source indices, and
   259→optionally a query:
   260→
   261→image::images/esql/esql-kibana-enrich-step-1.png[align="center",width="50%"]
   262→
   263→Click *Next* to select the match field and enrich fields:
   264→
   265→image::images/esql/esql-kibana-enrich-step-2.png[align="center",width="50%"]
   266→
   267→Finally, click *Create and execute*.
   268→
   269→Now, you can use the enrich policy in an {esql} query:
   270→
   271→[source,esql]
   272→----
   273→FROM kibana_sample_data_logs
   274→| STATS total_bytes = SUM(bytes) BY geo.dest
   275→| SORT total_bytes DESC
   276→| LIMIT 3
   277→| ENRICH countries
   278→----
   279→
   280→[discrete]
   281→[[esql-kibana-alerting-rule]]
   282→=== Create an alerting rule
   283→
   284→You can use {esql} queries to create alerts. From Discover, click *Alerts* and
   285→select *Create search threshold rule*. This opens a panel that enables you to
   286→create a rule using an {esql} query. Next, you can test the query, add a
   287→connector, and save the rule.
   288→
   289→image::images/esql/esql-kibana-create-rule.png[align="center",width=50%]
   290→
   291→[discrete]
   292→[[esql-kibana-limitations]]
   293→=== Limitations
   294→
   295→// tag::limitations[]
   296→* The user interface to filter data is not enabled when Discover is in {esql}
   297→mode. To filter data, write a query that uses the <<esql-where>> command
   298→instead.
   299→* Discover shows no more than 10,000 rows. This limit only applies to the number
   300→of rows that are retrieved by the query and displayed in Discover. Queries and
   301→aggregations run on the full data set.
   302→* Discover shows no more than 50 columns. If a query returns
   303→more than 50 columns, Discover only shows the first 50.
   304→* CSV export from Discover shows no more than 10,000 rows. This limit only applies to the number
   305→of rows that are retrieved by the query and displayed in Discover. Queries and
   306→aggregations run on the full data set.
   307→* Querying many indices at once without any filters can cause an error in
   308→kibana which looks like `[esql] > Unexpected error from Elasticsearch: The
   309→content length (536885793) is bigger than the maximum allowed string
   310→(536870888)`. The response from {esql} is too long. Use <<esql-drop>> or
   311→<<esql-keep>> to limit the number of fields returned.
   312→// end::limitations[]
   313→

{"type":"user","message":{"role":"user","content":[{"tool_use_id":"toolu_01GJmbfux6ve2q5mEVUPF9HC","type":"tool_result","content":"     1→// tag::console[]
     2→
     3→To get started with {esql} in Console, open the main menu and select
     4→*Dev Tools*.
     5→
     6→The general structure of an <<esql-query-api,{esql} query API>> request is:
     7→
     8→[source,txt]
     9→----
    10→POST /_query?format=txt
    11→{
    12→  "query": """
    13→
    14→  """
    15→}
    16→----
    17→
    18→Enter the actual {esql} query between the two sets of triple quotes. For
    19→example:
    20→
    21→[source,txt]
    22→----
    23→POST /_query?format=txt
    24→{
    25→  "query": """
    26→FROM sample_data
    27→  """
    28→}
    29→----
    30→// end::console[]
    31→
    32→
    33→// tag::discover[]
    34→
    35→include::../../esql/esql-kibana.asciidoc[tag=esql-mode]
    36→
    37→Adjust the time filter so it includes the timestamps in the sample data (October
    38→23rd, 2023).
    39→
    40→After switching to {esql} mode, the query bar shows a sample query. You can
    41→replace this query with the queries in this getting started guide.
    42→
    43→include::../../esql/esql-kibana.asciidoc[tag=autocomplete]
    44→
    45→include::../../esql/esql-kibana.asciidoc[tag=compact]
    46→
    47→// end::discover[]
    48→

{"type":"user","message":{"role":"user","content":[{"tool_use_id":"toolu_01EvZaVGvRtGe4Y3g8FjBK3v","type":"tool_result","content":"     1→[[esql-query-api]]
     2→=== {esql} query API
     3→++++
     4→<titleabbrev>{esql} query API</titleabbrev>
     5→++++
     6→
     7→Returns search results for an <<esql,ES|QL ({es} query language)>> query.
     8→
     9→[source,console]
    10→----
    11→POST /_query
    12→{
    13→  "query": """
    14→    FROM library
    15→    | EVAL year = DATE_TRUNC(1 YEARS, release_date)
    16→    | STATS MAX(page_count) BY year
    17→    | SORT year
    18→    | LIMIT 5
    19→  """
    20→}
    21→----
    22→// TEST[setup:library]
    23→
    24→[discrete]
    25→[[esql-query-api-request]]
    26→==== {api-request-title}
    27→
    28→`POST _query`
    29→
    30→[discrete]
    31→[[esql-query-api-prereqs]]
    32→==== {api-prereq-title}
    33→
    34→* If the {es} {security-features} are enabled, you must have the `read`
    35→<<privileges-list-indices,index privilege>> for the data stream, index,
    36→or alias you search.
    37→
    38→[discrete]
    39→[[esql-query-api-query-params]]
    40→==== {api-query-parms-title}
    41→
    42→`delimiter`::
    43→(Optional, string) Separator for CSV results. Defaults to `,`. The API only
    44→supports this parameter for CSV responses.
    45→
    46→`drop_null_columns`::
    47→(Optional, boolean) Should columns that are entirely `null` be removed from
    48→the `columns` and `values` portion of the results? Defaults to `false`. If
    49→`true` the the response will include an extra section under the name
    50→`all_columns` which has the name of all columns.
    51→
    52→`format`::
    53→(Optional, string) Format for the response. For valid values, refer to
    54→<<esql-rest-format>>.
    55→+
    56→You can also specify a format using the `Accept` HTTP header. If you specify
    57→both this parameter and the `Accept` HTTP header, this parameter takes
    58→precedence.
    59→
    60→[discrete]
    61→[role="child_attributes"]
    62→[[esql-query-api-request-body]]
    63→==== {api-request-body-title}
    64→
    65→`columnar`::
    66→(Optional, Boolean) If `true`, returns results in a columnar format. Defaults to
    67→`false`. The API only supports this parameter for CBOR, JSON, SMILE, and YAML
    68→responses. See <<esql-rest-columnar>>.
    69→
    70→`include_ccs_metadata`::
    71→(Optional, boolean) If `true`, cross-cluster searches will include metadata about the query
    72→on each cluster. Defaults to `false`. The API only supports this parameter for CBOR, JSON, SMILE,
    73→and YAML responses. See <<ccq-cluster-details>>.
    74→
    75→`locale`::
    76→(Optional, string) Returns results (especially dates) formatted per the conventions of the locale.
    77→For syntax, refer to <<esql-locale-param>>.
    78→
    79→`params`::
    80→(Optional, array) Values for parameters in the `query`. For syntax, refer to
    81→<<esql-rest-params>>.
    82→
    83→`profile`::
    84→(Optional, boolean) If provided and `true` the response will include an extra `profile` object
    85→with information about how the query was executed. It provides insight into the performance
    86→of each part of the query. This is for human debugging as the object's format might change at any time.
    87→Think of this like https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/sql-explain.html[EXPLAIN ANALYZE] or
    88→https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Query_plan[EXPLAIN PLAN].
    89→
    90→`query`::
    91→(Required, string) {esql} query to run. For syntax, refer to <<esql-syntax>>.
    92→
    93→
    94→ifeval::["{release-state}"=="unreleased"]
    95→`table`::
    96→(Optional, object) Named "table" parameters that can be referenced by the <<esql-lookup>> command.
    97→endif::[]
    98→
    99→[discrete]
   100→[role="child_attributes"]
   101→[[esql-query-api-response-body]]
   102→==== {api-response-body-title}
   103→
   104→`columns`::
   105→(array of objects)
   106→Column `name` and `type` for each column returned in `values`. Each object is a single column.
   107→
   108→`all_columns`::
   109→(array of objects)
   110→Column `name` and `type` for each queried column. Each object is a single column. This is only
   111→returned if `drop_null_columns` is sent with the request.
   112→
   113→`values`::
   114→(array of arrays)
   115→Values for the search results.
   116→
   117→`_clusters`::
   118→(object)
   119→Metadata about clusters involved in the execution of a cross-cluster query. Only returned (1) for
   120→cross-cluster searches and (2) when `include_ccs_metadata` is sent in the body and set to `true`
   121→and (3) when `format` of the response is set to JSON (the default), CBOR, SMILE, or YAML.
   122→See <<ccq-cluster-details>> for more information.
   123→
   124→`profile`::
   125→(object)
   126→Profile describing the execution of the query. Only returned if `profile` was sent in the body.
   127→The object itself is for human debugging and can change at any time. Think of this like
   128→https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/sql-explain.html[EXPLAIN ANALYZE] or
   129→https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Query_plan[EXPLAIN PLAN].
   130→

{"type":"user","message":{"role":"user","content":[{"tool_use_id":"toolu_01RSYbH2odvukRWm4EceiV8p","type":"tool_result","content":"     1→[[esql-rest]]
     2→=== {esql} REST API
     3→
     4→++++
     5→<titleabbrev>REST API</titleabbrev>
     6→++++
     7→
     8→[discrete]
     9→[[esql-rest-overview]]
    10→=== Overview
    11→
    12→The <<esql-query-api,{esql} query API>> accepts an {esql} query string in the
    13→`query` parameter, runs it, and returns the results. For example:
    14→
    15→[source,console]
    16→----
    17→POST /_query?format=txt
    18→{
    19→  "query": "FROM library | KEEP author, name, page_count, release_date | SORT page_count DESC | LIMIT 5"
    20→}
    21→----
    22→// TEST[setup:library]
    23→
    24→Which returns:
    25→
    26→[source,text]
    27→----
    28→     author      |        name        |  page_count   | release_date
    29→-----------------+--------------------+---------------+------------------------
    30→Peter F. Hamilton|Pandora's Star      |768            |2004-03-02T00:00:00.000Z
    31→Vernor Vinge     |A Fire Upon the Deep|613            |1992-06-01T00:00:00.000Z
    32→Frank Herbert    |Dune                |604            |1965-06-01T00:00:00.000Z
    33→Alastair Reynolds|Revelation Space    |585            |2000-03-15T00:00:00.000Z
    34→James S.A. Corey |Leviathan Wakes     |561            |2011-06-02T00:00:00.000Z
    35→----
    36→// TESTRESPONSE[s/\|/\\|/ s/\+/\\+/]
    37→// TESTRESPONSE[non_json]
    38→
    39→[discrete]
    40→[[esql-kibana-console]]
    41→==== Kibana Console
    42→
    43→If you are using {kibana-ref}/console-kibana.html[Kibana Console] (which is
    44→highly recommended), take advantage of the triple quotes `"""` when creating the
    45→query. This not only automatically escapes double quotes (`"`) inside the query
    46→string but also supports multi-line requests:
    47→
    48→// tag::esql-query-api[]
    49→[source,console]
    50→----
    51→POST /_query?format=txt
    52→{
    53→  "query": """
    54→    FROM library
    55→    | KEEP author, name, page_count, release_date
    56→    | SORT page_count DESC
    57→    | LIMIT 5
    58→  """
    59→}
    60→----
    61→// TEST[setup:library]
    62→
    63→[discrete]
    64→[[esql-rest-format]]
    65→==== Response formats
    66→
    67→{esql} can return the data in the following human readable and binary formats.
    68→You can set the format by specifying the `format` parameter in the URL or by
    69→setting the `Accept` or `Content-Type` HTTP header.
    70→
    71→NOTE: The URL parameter takes precedence over the HTTP headers. If neither is
    72→specified then the response is returned in the same format as the request.
    73→
    74→[cols="m,4m,8"]
    75→
    76→|===
    77→s|`format`
    78→s|HTTP header
    79→s|Description
    80→
    81→3+h| Human readable
    82→
    83→|csv
    84→|text/csv
    85→|{wikipedia}/Comma-separated_values[Comma-separated values]
    86→
    87→|json
    88→|application/json
    89→|https://www.json.org/[JSON] (JavaScript Object Notation) human-readable format
    90→
    91→|tsv
    92→|text/tab-separated-values
    93→|{wikipedia}/Tab-separated_values[Tab-separated values]
    94→
    95→|txt
    96→|text/plain
    97→|CLI-like representation
    98→
    99→|yaml
   100→|application/yaml
   101→|{wikipedia}/YAML[YAML] (YAML Ain't Markup Language) human-readable format
   102→
   103→3+h| Binary
   104→
   105→|cbor
   106→|application/cbor
   107→|https://cbor.io/[Concise Binary Object Representation]
   108→
   109→|smile
   110→|application/smile
   111→|{wikipedia}/Smile_(data_interchange_format)[Smile] binary data format similar
   112→to CBOR
   113→
   114→|arrow
   115→|application/vnd.apache.arrow.stream
   116→|**Experimental.** https://arrow.apache.org/[Apache Arrow] dataframes, https://arrow.apache.org/docs/format/Columnar.html#ipc-streaming-format[IPC streaming format]
   117→|===
   118→
   119→The `csv` format accepts a formatting URL query attribute, `delimiter`, which
   120→indicates which character should be used to separate the CSV values. It defaults
   121→to comma (`,`) and cannot take any of the following values: double quote (`"`),
   122→carriage-return (`\r`) and new-line (`\n`). The tab (`\t`) can also not be used.
   123→Use the `tsv` format instead.
   124→
   125→[discrete]
   126→[[esql-rest-filtering]]
   127→==== Filtering using {es} Query DSL
   128→
   129→Specify a Query DSL query in the `filter` parameter to filter the set of
   130→documents that an {esql} query runs on.
   131→
   132→[source,console]
   133→----
   134→POST /_query?format=txt
   135→{
   136→  "query": """
   137→    FROM library
   138→    | KEEP author, name, page_count, release_date
   139→    | SORT page_count DESC
   140→    | LIMIT 5
   141→  """,
   142→  "filter": {
   143→    "range": {
   144→      "page_count": {
   145→        "gte": 100,
   146→        "lte": 200
   147→      }
   148→    }
   149→  }
   150→}
   151→----
   152→// TEST[setup:library]
   153→
   154→Which returns:
   155→
   156→[source,text]
   157→--------------------------------------------------
   158→    author     |                name                |  page_count   | release_date
   159→---------------+------------------------------------+---------------+------------------------
   160→Douglas Adams  |The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy|180            |1979-10-12T00:00:00.000Z
   161→--------------------------------------------------
   162→// TESTRESPONSE[s/\|/\\|/ s/\+/\\+/]
   163→// TESTRESPONSE[non_json]
   164→
   165→[discrete]
   166→[[esql-rest-columnar]]
   167→==== Columnar results
   168→
   169→By default, {esql} returns results as rows. For example, `FROM` returns each
   170→individual document as one row. For the `json`, `yaml`, `cbor` and `smile`
   171→<<esql-rest-format,formats>>, {esql} can return the results in a columnar
   172→fashion where one row represents all the values of a certain column in the
   173→results.
   174→
   175→[source,console]
   176→----
   177→POST /_query?format=json
   178→{
   179→  "query": """
   180→    FROM library
   181→    | KEEP author, name, page_count, release_date
   182→    | SORT page_count DESC
   183→    | LIMIT 5
   184→  """,
   185→  "columnar": true
   186→}
   187→----
   188→// TEST[setup:library]
   189→
   190→Which returns:
   191→
   192→[source,console-result]
   193→----
   194→{
   195→  "took": 28,
   196→  "columns": [
   197→    {"name": "author", "type": "text"},
   198→    {"name": "name", "type": "text"},
   199→    {"name": "page_count", "type": "integer"},
   200→    {"name": "release_date", "type": "date"}
   201→  ],
   202→  "values": [
   203→    ["Peter F. Hamilton", "Vernor Vinge", "Frank Herbert", "Alastair Reynolds", "James S.A. Corey"],
   204→    ["Pandora's Star", "A Fire Upon the Deep", "Dune", "Revelation Space", "Leviathan Wakes"],
   205→    [768, 613, 604, 585, 561],
   206→    ["2004-03-02T00:00:00.000Z", "1992-06-01T00:00:00.000Z", "1965-06-01T00:00:00.000Z", "2000-03-15T00:00:00.000Z", "2011-06-02T00:00:00.000Z"]
   207→  ]
   208→}
   209→----
   210→// TESTRESPONSE[s/"took": 28/"took": "$body.took"/]
   211→
   212→[discrete]
   213→[[esql-locale-param]]
   214→==== Returning localized results
   215→
   216→Use the `locale` parameter in the request body to return results (especially dates) formatted per the conventions of the locale.
   217→If `locale` is not specified, defaults to `en-US` (English).
   218→Refer to https://www.oracle.com/java/technologies/javase/jdk17-suported-locales.html[JDK Supported Locales].
   219→
   220→Syntax: the `locale` parameter accepts language tags in the (case-insensitive) format `xy` and `xy-XY`.
   221→
   222→For example, to return a month name in French:
   223→
   224→[source,console]
   225→----
   226→POST /_query
   227→{
   228→  "locale": "fr-FR",
   229→  "query": """
   230→          ROW birth_date_string = "2023-01-15T00:00:00.000Z"
   231→          | EVAL birth_date = date_parse(birth_date_string)
   232→          | EVAL month_of_birth = DATE_FORMAT("MMMM",birth_date)
   233→          | LIMIT 5
   234→   """
   235→}
   236→----
   237→// TEST[setup:library]
   238→
   239→[discrete]
   240→[[esql-rest-params]]
   241→==== Passing parameters to a query
   242→
   243→Values, for example for a condition, can be passed to a query "inline", by
   244→integrating the value in the query string itself:
   245→
   246→[source,console]
   247→----
   248→POST /_query
   249→{
   250→  "query": """
   251→    FROM library
   252→    | EVAL year = DATE_EXTRACT("year", release_date)
   253→    | WHERE page_count > 300 AND author == "Frank Herbert"
   254→    | STATS count = COUNT(*) by year
   255→    | WHERE count > 0
   256→    | LIMIT 5
   257→  """
   258→}
   259→----
   260→// TEST[setup:library]
   261→
   262→To avoid any attempts of hacking or code injection, extract the values in a
   263→separate list of parameters. Use question mark placeholders (`?`) in the query
   264→string for each of the parameters:
   265→
   266→[source,console]
   267→----
   268→POST /_query
   269→{
   270→  "query": """
   271→    FROM library
   272→    | EVAL year = DATE_EXTRACT("year", release_date)
   273→    | WHERE page_count > ? AND author == ?
   274→    | STATS count = COUNT(*) by year
   275→    | WHERE count > ?
   276→    | LIMIT 5
   277→  """,
   278→  "params": [300, "Frank Herbert", 0]
   279→}
   280→----
   281→// TEST[setup:library]
   282→
   283→The parameters can be named parameters or positional parameters.
   284→
   285→Named parameters use question mark placeholders (`?`) followed by a string.
   286→
   287→[source,console]
   288→----
   289→POST /_query
   290→{
   291→  "query": """
   292→    FROM library
   293→    | EVAL year = DATE_EXTRACT("year", release_date)
   294→    | WHERE page_count > ?page_count AND author == ?author
   295→    | STATS count = COUNT(*) by year
   296→    | WHERE count > ?count
   297→    | LIMIT 5
   298→  """,
   299→  "params": [{"page_count" : 300}, {"author" : "Frank Herbert"}, {"count" : 0}]
   300→}
   301→----
   302→// TEST[setup:library]
   303→
   304→Positional parameters use question mark placeholders (`?`) followed by an
   305→integer.
   306→
   307→[source,console]
   308→----
   309→POST /_query
   310→{
   311→  "query": """
   312→    FROM library
   313→    | EVAL year = DATE_EXTRACT("year", release_date)
   314→    | WHERE page_count > ?1 AND author == ?2
   315→    | STATS count = COUNT(*) by year
   316→    | WHERE count > ?3
   317→    | LIMIT 5
   318→  """,
   319→  "params": [300, "Frank Herbert", 0]
   320→}
   321→----
   322→// TEST[setup:library]
   323→
   324→[discrete]
   325→[[esql-rest-async-query]]
   326→==== Running an async {esql} query
   327→
   328→The <<esql-async-query-api,{esql} async query API>> lets you asynchronously
   329→execute a query request, monitor its progress, and retrieve results when
   330→they become available.
   331→
   332→Executing an {esql} query is commonly quite fast, however queries across
   333→large data sets or frozen data can take some time. To avoid long waits,
   334→run an async {esql} query.
   335→
   336→Queries initiated by the async query API may return results or not. The
   337→`wait_for_completion_timeout` property determines how long to wait for
   338→the results. If the results are not available by this time, a
   339→<<esql-async-query-api-response-body-query-id,query id>> is returned which
   340→can be later used to retrieve the results. For example:
   341→
   342→[source,console]
   343→----
   344→POST /_query/async
   345→{
   346→  "query": """
   347→    FROM library
   348→    | EVAL year = DATE_TRUNC(1 YEARS, release_date)
   349→    | STATS MAX(page_count) BY year
   350→    | SORT year
   351→    | LIMIT 5
   352→  """,
   353→  "wait_for_completion_timeout": "2s"
   354→}
   355→----
   356→// TEST[setup:library]
   357→// TEST[skip:awaitsfix https://github.com/elastic/elasticsearch/issues/104013]
   358→
   359→If the results are not available within the given timeout period, 2
   360→seconds in this case, no results are returned but rather a response that
   361→includes:
   362→
   363→* A query ID
   364→* An `is_running` value of _true_, indicating the query is ongoing
   365→
   366→The query continues to run in the background without blocking other
   367→requests.
   368→
   369→[source,console-result]
   370→----
   371→{
   372→  "id": "FmNJRUZ1YWZCU3dHY1BIOUhaenVSRkEaaXFlZ3h4c1RTWFNocDdnY2FSaERnUTozNDE=",
   373→  "is_running": true
   374→}
   375→----
   376→// TEST[skip: no access to query ID - may return response values]
   377→
   378→To check the progress of an async query, use the <<esql-async-query-get-api,
   379→{esql} async query get API>> with the query ID. Specify how long you'd like
   380→to wait for complete results in the `wait_for_completion_timeout` parameter.
   381→
   382→[source,console]
   383→----
   384→GET /_query/async/FmNJRUZ1YWZCU3dHY1BIOUhaenVSRkEaaXFlZ3h4c1RTWFNocDdnY2FSaERnUTozNDE=?wait_for_completion_timeout=30s
   385→----
   386→// TEST[skip: no access to query ID - may return response values]
   387→
   388→If the response's `is_running` value is `false`, the query has finished
   389→and the results are returned, along with the `took` time for the query.
   390→
   391→[source,console-result]
   392→----
   393→{
   394→  "is_running": false,
   395→  "took": 48,
   396→  "columns": ...
   397→}
   398→----
   399→// TEST[skip: no access to query ID - may return response values]
   400→
   401→Use the <<esql-async-query-delete-api, {esql} async query delete API>> to
   402→delete an async query before the `keep_alive` period ends. If the query
   403→is still running, {es} cancels it.
   404→
   405→[source,console]
   406→----
   407→DELETE /_query/async/FmdMX2pIang3UWhLRU5QS0lqdlppYncaMUpYQ05oSkpTc3kwZ21EdC1tbFJXQToxOTI=
   408→----
   409→// TEST[skip: no access to query ID]
   410→
   411→

{"type":"user","message":{"role":"user","content":[{"tool_use_id":"toolu_01BSb2rVEHj1uPDPzAxnrdGs","type":"tool_result","content":"   170→[discrete]
   171→[[esql-kibana-time-filter]]
   172→=== Time filtering
   173→
   174→To display data within a specified time range, use the
   175→{kibana-ref}/set-time-filter.html[time filter]. The time filter is only enabled
   176→when the indices you're querying have a field called `@timestamp`.
   177→
   178→If your indices do not have a timestamp field called `@timestamp`, you can limit
   179→the time range using the <<esql-where>> command and the <<esql-now>> function.
   180→For example, if the timestamp field is called `timestamp`, to query the last 15
   181→minutes of data:
   182→[source,esql]
   183→----
   184→FROM kibana_sample_data_logs
   185→| WHERE timestamp > NOW() - 15minutes
   186→----
   187→
   188→[discrete]
   189→[[esql-kibana-visualizations]]
   190→=== Analyze and visualize data
   191→
   192→Between the query bar and the results table, Discover shows a date histogram
   193→visualization. If the indices you're querying do not contain a `@timestamp`
   194→field, the histogram is not shown.
   195→
   196→The visualization adapts to the query. A query's nature determines the type of
   197→visualization. For example, this query aggregates the total number of bytes per
   198→destination country:
   199→
   200→[source,esql]
   201→----
   202→FROM kibana_sample_data_logs
   203→| STATS total_bytes = SUM(bytes) BY geo.dest
   204→| SORT total_bytes DESC
   205→| LIMIT 3
   206→----
   207→
   208→The resulting visualization is a bar chart showing the top 3 countries:
   209→
   210→image::images/esql/esql-kibana-bar-chart.png[align="center"]
   211→
   212→To make changes to the visualization, like changing the visualization type, axes and colors, click the
   213→pencil button (image:images/esql/esql-icon-edit-visualization.svg[]). This opens
   214→an in-line editor:
   215→
   216→image::images/esql/esql-kibana-in-line-editor.png[align="center",width=66%]
   217→
   218→You can save the visualization to a new or existing dashboard by clicking the
   219→save button (image:images/esql/esql-icon-save-visualization.svg[]). Once saved

{"type":"user","message":{"role":"user","content":[{"tool_use_id":"toolu_01Hn9GhNhF3jfee5JaVxrrH9","type":"tool_result","content":"   240→[[esql-rest-params]]
   241→==== Passing parameters to a query
   242→
   243→Values, for example for a condition, can be passed to a query "inline", by
   244→integrating the value in the query string itself:
   245→
   246→[source,console]
   247→----
   248→POST /_query
   249→{
   250→  "query": """
   251→    FROM library
   252→    | EVAL year = DATE_EXTRACT("year", release_date)
   253→    | WHERE page_count > 300 AND author == "Frank Herbert"
   254→    | STATS count = COUNT(*) by year
   255→    | WHERE count > 0
   256→    | LIMIT 5
   257→  """
   258→}
   259→----
   260→// TEST[setup:library]
   261→
   262→To avoid any attempts of hacking or code injection, extract the values in a
   263→separate list of parameters. Use question mark placeholders (`?`) in the query
   264→string for each of the parameters:
   265→
   266→[source,console]
   267→----
   268→POST /_query
   269→{
   270→  "query": """
   271→    FROM library
   272→    | EVAL year = DATE_EXTRACT("year", release_date)
   273→    | WHERE page_count > ? AND author == ?
   274→    | STATS count = COUNT(*) by year
   275→    | WHERE count > ?
   276→    | LIMIT 5
   277→  """,
   278→  "params": [300, "Frank Herbert", 0]
   279→}
   280→----
   281→// TEST[setup:library]
   282→
   283→The parameters can be named parameters or positional parameters.
   284→
   285→Named parameters use question mark placeholders (`?`) followed by a string.
   286→
   287→[source,console]
   288→----
   289→POST /_query
   290→{
   291→  "query": """
   292→    FROM library
   293→    | EVAL year = DATE_EXTRACT("year", release_date)
   294→    | WHERE page_count > ?page_count AND author == ?author
   295→    | STATS count = COUNT(*) by year
   296→    | WHERE count > ?count
   297→    | LIMIT 5
   298→  """,
   299→  "params": [{"page_count" : 300}, {"author" : "Frank Herbert"}, {"count" : 0}]
   300→}
   301→----
   302→// TEST[setup:library]
   303→
   304→Positional parameters use question mark placeholders (`?`) followed by an
   305→integer.
   306→
   307→[source,console]
   308→----
   309→POST /_query
   310→{
   311→  "query": """
   312→    FROM library
   313→    | EVAL year = DATE_EXTRACT("year", release_date)
   314→    | WHERE page_count > ?1 AND author == ?2
   315→    | STATS count = COUNT(*) by year
   316→    | WHERE count > ?3
   317→    | LIMIT 5
   318→  """,
   319→  "params": [300, "Frank Herbert", 0]
   320→}
   321→----
   322→// TEST[setup:library]
   323→
   324→[discrete]
   325→[[esql-rest-async-query]]
   326→==== Running an async {esql} query
   327→
   328→The <<esql-async-query-api,{esql} async query API>> lets you asynchronously
   329→execute a query request, monitor its progress, and retrieve results when
   330→they become available.
   331→
   332→Executing an {esql} query is commonly quite fast, however queries across
   333→large data sets or frozen data can take some time. To avoid long waits,
   334→run an async {esql} query.
   335→
   336→Queries initiated by the async query API may return results or not. The
   337→`wait_for_completion_timeout` property determines how long to wait for
   338→the results. If the results are not available by this time, a
   339→<<esql-async-query-api-response-body-query-id,query id>> is returned which

{"type":"user","message":{"role":"user","content":[{"tool_use_id":"toolu_01Q5F8uEv8LKVx2jHH3Y1mWA","type":"tool_result","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Excellent! Now I have comprehensive findings. Let me create a final summary document:

## Summary of Findings

Based on my thorough search through the Elasticsearch documentation repository, here are the most relevant files containing documentation about Kibana ES|QL time filters:

### Primary Documentation Files

**1. /private/var/folders/1t/tn_3vh3x0nv_snwb7xrv97th0000gn/T/tmpoq4qpnkr/workspace/docs/reference/esql/esql-kibana.asciidoc**

This is the **primary source file** for Kibana ES|QL documentation. It contains:
- Section `[[esql-kibana-time-filter]]` starting at line 171: "=== Time filtering"
- Documentation explaining how Kibana time filters work with ES|QL queries
- Reference to Kibana's time filter UI with link to `{kibana-ref}/set-time-filter.html[time filter]`
- Information that time filters are only enabled when indices have an `@timestamp` field
- Alternative methods using the `WHERE` command and `NOW()` function for custom timestamp field filtering

Key excerpt from lines 174-186:
```
To display data within a specified time range, use the
{kibana-ref}/set-time-filter.html[time filter]. The time filter is only enabled
when the indices you're querying have a field called `@timestamp`.

If your indices do not have a timestamp field called `@timestamp`, you can limit
the time range using the <<esql-where>> command and the <<esql-now>> function.
For example, if the timestamp field is called `timestamp`, to query the last 15
minutes of data:
FROM kibana_sample_data_logs
| WHERE timestamp > NOW() - 15minutes
```

### Supporting Documentation Files

**2. /private/var/folders/1t/tn_3vh3x0nv_snwb7xrv97th0000gn/T/tmpoq4qpnkr/workspace/docs/reference/esql/esql-rest.asciidoc**

Contains the REST API documentation for ES|QL with important sections:
- Section `[[esql-rest-params]]` (lines 240-322): "Passing parameters to a query"
- Shows how to pass query parameters using the `params` field in the request body
- Documents three parameter passing methods:
  - Inline values (direct in query string)
  - Positional parameters with `?` placeholders
  - Named parameters with `?paramname` placeholders

**3. /private/var/folders/1t/tn_3vh3x0nv_snwb7xrv97th0000gn/T/tmpoq4qpnkr/workspace/docs/reference/esql/esql-query-api.asciidoc**

The ES|QL Query API reference documentation that defines:
- The `params` request body field (lines 79-81) for passing values to queries
- Complete API specification for the `POST /_query` endpoint

**4. /private/var/folders/1t/tn_3vh3x0nv_snwb7xrv97th0000gn/T/tmpoq4qpnkr/workspace/rest-api-spec/src/main/resources/rest-api-spec/api/esql.query.json**

The REST API specification file in JSON format defining the official ES|QL query endpoint parameters and expected request/response structure.

### Additional Related Files

**5. /private/var/folders/1t/tn_3vh3x0nv_snwb7xrv97th0000gn/T/tmpoq4qpnkr/workspace/docs/reference/tab-widgets/esql/esql-getting-started-discover-console.asciidoc**

Getting started guide that references time filter setup in Kibana Discover mode.

**6. /private/var/folders/1t/tn_3vh3x0nv_snwb7xrv97th0000gn/T/tmpoq4qpnkr/workspace/docs/reference/esql/functions/description/now.asciidoc**

Documentation for the `NOW()` function used in time filtering queries.

### Important Notes About _tstart and _tend Parameters

Based on my comprehensive search, I found:
- The documentation does **not explicitly mention `?_tstart` and `?_tend`** as named parameters in the found files
- The time filter in Kibana likely passes time range information through Kibana's UI layer rather than as direct query parameters in the API request
- When Kibana applies a time filter to an ES|QL query in Discover, it likely converts the selected time range into filter operations applied to the data
- Users can manually specify time ranges in queries using the `NOW()` function combined with `WHERE` clauses (as shown in the esql-kibana.asciidoc documentation)

The preview URL reference to "esql-kibana.html#esql-kibana-time-filter" points to the section in the esql-kibana.asciidoc file at line 171 with the section ID `[[esql-kibana-time-filter]]`."}]}]},"parent_tool_use_id":null,"session_id":"7c90dd25-ecac-479f-a611-964de795cd83","uuid":"ef613f51-5f65-4efa-bb9c-4ab4c936f7d1"}

{"type":"user","message":{"role":"user","content":[{"tool_use_id":"toolu_013J2Vru2RJEW9XuWBraqY26","type":"tool_result","content":"     1→[[esql-kibana]]
     2→=== Using {esql} in {kib}
     3→
     4→++++
     5→<titleabbrev>Using {esql} in {kib}</titleabbrev>
     6→++++
     7→
     8→You can use {esql} in {kib} to query and aggregate your data, create
     9→visualizations, and set up alerts.
    10→
    11→This guide shows you how to use {esql} in Kibana. To follow along with the
    12→queries, load the "Sample web logs" sample data set by clicking *Try sample
    13→data* from the {kib} Home, selecting *Other sample data sets*, and clicking *Add
    14→data* on the *Sample web logs* card.
    15→
    16→[discrete]
    17→[[esql-kibana-enable]]
    18→=== Enable or disable {esql}
    19→
    20→{esql} is enabled by default in {kib}. It can be
    21→disabled using the `enableESQL` setting from the
    22→{kibana-ref}/advanced-options.html[Advanced Settings].
    23→
    24→This will hide the {esql} user interface from various applications.
    25→However, users will be able to access existing {esql} artifacts like saved searches and visualizations.
    26→
    27→[discrete]
    28→[[esql-kibana-get-started]]
    29→=== Get started with {esql}
    30→
    31→// tag::esql-mode[]
    32→To get started with {esql} in Discover, open the main menu and select
    33→*Discover*. Next, from the Data views menu, select *Language: ES|QL*.
    34→
    35→image::images/esql/esql-data-view-menu.png[align="center",width=33%]
    36→// end::esql-mode[]
    37→
    38→[discrete]
    39→[[esql-kibana-query-bar]]
    40→=== The query bar
    41→
    42→After switching to {esql} mode, the query bar shows a sample query. For example:
    43→
    44→[source,esql]
    45→----
    46→from kibana_sample_data_logs | limit 10
    47→----
    48→
    49→Every query starts with a <<esql-commands,source command>>. In this query, the
    50→source command is <<esql-from>>. `FROM` retrieves data from data streams, indices, or
    51→aliases. In this example, the data is retrieved from `kibana_sample_data_logs`.
    52→
    53→A source command can be followed by one or more <<esql-commands,processing
    54→commands>>. In this query, the processing command is <<esql-limit>>. `LIMIT`
    55→limits the number of rows that are retrieved.
    56→
    57→TIP: Click the help icon (image:images/esql/esql-icon-help.svg[Static,20]) to open the
    58→in-product reference documentation for all commands and functions.
    59→
    60→// tag::autocomplete[]
    61→To make it easier to write queries, auto-complete offers suggestions with
    62→possible commands and functions:
    63→
    64→image::images/esql/esql-kibana-auto-complete.png[align="center"]
    65→// end::autocomplete[]
    66→
    67→[NOTE]
    68→====
    69→{esql} keywords are case-insensitive. The following query is identical to the
    70→previous one:
    71→
    72→[source,esql]
    73→----
    74→FROM kibana_sample_data_logs | LIMIT 10
    75→----
    76→====
    77→
    78→[discrete]
    79→==== Expand the query bar
    80→
    81→For readability, you can put each processing command on a new line. The
    82→following query is identical to the previous one:
    83→
    84→[source,esql]
    85→----
    86→FROM kibana_sample_data_logs
    87→| LIMIT 10
    88→----
    89→
    90→// tag::compact[]
    91→To make it easier to write multi-line queries, click the double-headed arrow
    92→button (image:images/esql/esql-icon-expand-query-bar.svg[]) to expand the query
    93→bar:
    94→
    95→image::images/esql/esql-expanded-query-bar.png[align="center"]
    96→
    97→To return to a compact query bar, click the minimize editor button
    98→(image:images/esql/esql-icon-minimize-query-bar.svg[]).
    99→// end::compact[]
   100→
   101→[discrete]
   102→==== Warnings
   103→
   104→A query may result in warnings, for example when querying an unsupported field
   105→type. When that happens, a warning symbol is shown in the query bar. To see the
   106→detailed warning, expand the query bar, and click *warnings*.
   107→
   108→[discrete]
   109→[[esql-kibana-query-history]]
   110→==== Query history
   111→
   112→You can reuse your recent {esql} queries in the query bar.
   113→In the query bar click *Show recent queries*:
   114→
   115→image::images/esql/esql-discover-show-recent-query.png[align="center",size="50%"]
   116→
   117→You can then scroll through your recent queries:
   118→
   119→image::images/esql/esql-discover-query-history.png[align="center",size="50%"]
   120→
   121→[discrete]
   122→[[esql-kibana-results-table]]
   123→=== The results table
   124→
   125→For the example query, the results table shows 10 rows. Omitting the `LIMIT`
   126→command, the results table defaults to up to 1000 rows. Using `LIMIT`, you can
   127→increase the limit to up to 10,000 rows.
   128→
   129→NOTE: the 10,000 row limit only applies to the number of rows that are retrieved
   130→by the query and displayed in Discover. Any query or aggregation runs on the
   131→full data set.
   132→
   133→Each row shows two columns for the example query: a column with the `@timestamp`
   134→field and a column with the full document. To display specific fields from the
   135→documents, use the <<esql-keep>> command:
   136→
   137→[source,esql]
   138→----
   139→FROM kibana_sample_data_logs
   140→| KEEP @timestamp, bytes, geo.dest
   141→----
   142→
   143→To display all fields as separate columns, use `KEEP *`:
   144→
   145→[source,esql]
   146→----
   147→FROM kibana_sample_data_logs
   148→| KEEP *
   149→----
   150→
   151→NOTE: The maximum number of columns in Discover is 50. If a query returns more
   152→than 50 columns, Discover only shows the first 50.
   153→
   154→[discrete]
   155→==== Sorting
   156→
   157→To sort on one of the columns, click the column name you want to sort on and
   158→select the sort order. Note that this performs client-side sorting. It only
   159→sorts the rows that were retrieved by the query, which may not be the full
   160→dataset because of the (implicit) limit. To sort the full data set, use the
   161→<<esql-sort>> command:
   162→
   163→[source,esql]
   164→----
   165→FROM kibana_sample_data_logs
   166→| KEEP @timestamp, bytes, geo.dest
   167→| SORT bytes DESC
   168→----
   169→
   170→[discrete]
   171→[[esql-kibana-time-filter]]
   172→=== Time filtering
   173→
   174→To display data within a specified time range, use the
   175→{kibana-ref}/set-time-filter.html[time filter]. The time filter is only enabled
   176→when the indices you're querying have a field called `@timestamp`.
   177→
   178→If your indices do not have a timestamp field called `@timestamp`, you can limit
   179→the time range using the <<esql-where>> command and the <<esql-now>> function.
   180→For example, if the timestamp field is called `timestamp`, to query the last 15
   181→minutes of data:
   182→[source,esql]
   183→----
   184→FROM kibana_sample_data_logs
   185→| WHERE timestamp > NOW() - 15minutes
   186→----
   187→
   188→[discrete]
   189→[[esql-kibana-visualizations]]
   190→=== Analyze and visualize data
   191→
   192→Between the query bar and the results table, Discover shows a date histogram
   193→visualization. If the indices you're querying do not contain a `@timestamp`
   194→field, the histogram is not shown.
   195→
   196→The visualization adapts to the query. A query's nature determines the type of
   197→visualization. For example, this query aggregates the total number of bytes per
   198→destination country:
   199→
   200→[source,esql]
   201→----
   202→FROM kibana_sample_data_logs
   203→| STATS total_bytes = SUM(bytes) BY geo.dest
   204→| SORT total_bytes DESC
   205→| LIMIT 3
   206→----
   207→
   208→The resulting visualization is a bar chart showing the top 3 countries:
   209→
   210→image::images/esql/esql-kibana-bar-chart.png[align="center"]
   211→
   212→To make changes to the visualization, like changing the visualization type, axes and colors, click the
   213→pencil button (image:images/esql/esql-icon-edit-visualization.svg[]). This opens
   214→an in-line editor:
   215→
   216→image::images/esql/esql-kibana-in-line-editor.png[align="center",width=66%]
   217→
   218→You can save the visualization to a new or existing dashboard by clicking the
   219→save button (image:images/esql/esql-icon-save-visualization.svg[]). Once saved
   220→to a dashboard, you'll be taken to the Dashboards page. You can continue to 
   221→make changes to the visualization. Click the
   222→options button in the top-right (image:images/esql/esql-icon-options.svg[]) and
   223→select *Edit ESQL visualization* to open the in-line editor:
   224→
   225→image::images/esql/esql-kibana-edit-on-dashboard.png[align="center",width=66%]
   226→
   227→[discrete]
   228→[[esql-kibana-dashboard-panel]]
   229→==== Add a panel to a dashboard
   230→
   231→You can use {esql} queries to create panels on your dashboards.
   232→To add a panel to a dashboard, under *Dashboards*, click the *Add panel* button and select {esql}.
   233→
   234→image::images/esql/esql-dashboard-panel.png[align="center",width=50%]
   235→
   236→Check the {esql} query by clicking the Panel filters button (image:images/esql/dashboard_panel_filter_button.png[Panel filters button on panel header]):
   237→
   238→image::images/esql/esql-dashboard-panel-query.png[align="center",width=50%]
   239→
   240→You can also edit the {esql} visualization from here.
   241→Click the options button in the top-right (image:images/esql/esql-icon-options.svg[]) and
   242→select *Edit ESQL visualization* to open the in-line editor.
   243→
   244→image::images/esql/esql-dashboard-panel-edit-visualization.png[align="center",width=50%]
   245→
   246→[discrete]
   247→[[esql-kibana-enrich]]
   248→=== Create an enrich policy
   249→
   250→The {esql} <<esql-enrich>> command enables you to <<esql-enrich-data,enrich>>
   251→your query dataset with fields from another dataset. Before you can use
   252→`ENRICH`, you need to <<esql-set-up-enrich-policy,create and execute an enrich
   253→policy>>. If a policy exists, it will be suggested by auto-complete. If not,
   254→click *Click to create* to create one.
   255→
   256→image::images/esql/esql-kibana-enrich-autocomplete.png[align="center"]
   257→
   258→Next, you can enter a policy name, the policy type, source indices, and
   259→optionally a query:
   260→
   261→image::images/esql/esql-kibana-enrich-step-1.png[align="center",width="50%"]
   262→
   263→Click *Next* to select the match field and enrich fields:
   264→
   265→image::images/esql/esql-kibana-enrich-step-2.png[align="center",width="50%"]
   266→
   267→Finally, click *Create and execute*.
   268→
   269→Now, you can use the enrich policy in an {esql} query:
   270→
   271→[source,esql]
   272→----
   273→FROM kibana_sample_data_logs
   274→| STATS total_bytes = SUM(bytes) BY geo.dest
   275→| SORT total_bytes DESC
   276→| LIMIT 3
   277→| ENRICH countries
   278→----
   279→
   280→[discrete]
   281→[[esql-kibana-alerting-rule]]
   282→=== Create an alerting rule
   283→
   284→You can use {esql} queries to create alerts. From Discover, click *Alerts* and
   285→select *Create search threshold rule*. This opens a panel that enables you to
   286→create a rule using an {esql} query. Next, you can test the query, add a
   287→connector, and save the rule.
   288→
   289→image::images/esql/esql-kibana-create-rule.png[align="center",width=50%]
   290→
   291→[discrete]
   292→[[esql-kibana-limitations]]
   293→=== Limitations
   294→
   295→// tag::limitations[]
   296→* The user interface to filter data is not enabled when Discover is in {esql}
   297→mode. To filter data, write a query that uses the <<esql-where>> command
   298→instead.
   299→* Discover shows no more than 10,000 rows. This limit only applies to the number
   300→of rows that are retrieved by the query and displayed in Discover. Queries and
   301→aggregations run on the full data set.
   302→* Discover shows no more than 50 columns. If a query returns
   303→more than 50 columns, Discover only shows the first 50.
   304→* CSV export from Discover shows no more than 10,000 rows. This limit only applies to the number
   305→of rows that are retrieved by the query and displayed in Discover. Queries and
   306→aggregations run on the full data set.
   307→* Querying many indices at once without any filters can cause an error in
   308→kibana which looks like `[esql] > Unexpected error from Elasticsearch: The
   309→content length (536885793) is bigger than the maximum allowed string
   310→(536870888)`. The response from {esql} is too long. Use <<esql-drop>> or
   311→<<esql-keep>> to limit the number of fields returned.
   312→// end::limitations[]
   313→

{"type":"user","message":{"role":"user","content":[{"tool_use_id":"toolu_012pBbXraygfmXmBA8atqScL","type":"tool_result","content":"   240→[[esql-rest-params]]
   241→==== Passing parameters to a query
   242→
   243→Values, for example for a condition, can be passed to a query "inline", by
   244→integrating the value in the query string itself:
   245→
   246→[source,console]
   247→----
   248→POST /_query
   249→{
   250→  "query": """
   251→    FROM library
   252→    | EVAL year = DATE_EXTRACT("year", release_date)
   253→    | WHERE page_count > 300 AND author == "Frank Herbert"
   254→    | STATS count = COUNT(*) by year
   255→    | WHERE count > 0
   256→    | LIMIT 5
   257→  """
   258→}
   259→----
   260→// TEST[setup:library]
   261→
   262→To avoid any attempts of hacking or code injection, extract the values in a
   263→separate list of parameters. Use question mark placeholders (`?`) in the query
   264→string for each of the parameters:
   265→
   266→[source,console]
   267→----
   268→POST /_query
   269→{
   270→  "query": """
   271→    FROM library
   272→    | EVAL year = DATE_EXTRACT("year", release_date)
   273→    | WHERE page_count > ? AND author == ?
   274→    | STATS count = COUNT(*) by year
   275→    | WHERE count > ?
   276→    | LIMIT 5
   277→  """,
   278→  "params": [300, "Frank Herbert", 0]
   279→}
   280→----
   281→// TEST[setup:library]
   282→
   283→The parameters can be named parameters or positional parameters.
   284→
   285→Named parameters use question mark placeholders (`?`) followed by a string.
   286→
   287→[source,console]
   288→----
   289→POST /_query
   290→{
   291→  "query": """
   292→    FROM library
   293→    | EVAL year = DATE_EXTRACT("year", release_date)
   294→    | WHERE page_count > ?page_count AND author == ?author
   295→    | STATS count = COUNT(*) by year
   296→    | WHERE count > ?count
   297→    | LIMIT 5
   298→  """,
   299→  "params": [{"page_count" : 300}, {"author" : "Frank Herbert"}, {"count" : 0}]
   300→}
   301→----
   302→// TEST[setup:library]
   303→
   304→Positional parameters use question mark placeholders (`?`) followed by an
   305→integer.
   306→
   307→[source,console]
   308→----
   309→POST /_query
   310→{
   311→  "query": """
   312→    FROM library
   313→    | EVAL year = DATE_EXTRACT("year", release_date)
   314→    | WHERE page_count > ?1 AND author == ?2
   315→    | STATS count = COUNT(*) by year
   316→    | WHERE count > ?3
   317→    | LIMIT 5
   318→  """,
   319→  "params": [300, "Frank Herbert", 0]
   320→}
   321→----
   322→// TEST[setup:library]
   323→
   324→[discrete]
   325→[[esql-rest-async-query]]
   326→==== Running an async {esql} query
   327→
   328→The <<esql-async-query-api,{esql} async query API>> lets you asynchronously
   329→execute a query request, monitor its progress, and retrieve results when
   330→they become available.
   331→
   332→Executing an {esql} query is commonly quite fast, however queries across
   333→large data sets or frozen data can take some time. To avoid long waits,
   334→run an async {esql} query.
   335→
   336→Queries initiated by the async query API may return results or not. The
   337→`wait_for_completion_timeout` property determines how long to wait for
   338→the results. If the results are not available by this time, a
   339→<<esql-async-query-api-response-body-query-id,query id>> is returned which

[[esql-kibana-time-filter]]
=== Time filtering

To display data within a specified time range, use the
{kibana-ref}/set-time-filter.html[time filter]. The time filter is only enabled
when the indices you're querying have a field called `@timestamp`.

If your indices do not have a timestamp field called `@timestamp`, you can limit
the time range using the <<esql-where>> command and the <<esql-now>> function.
For example, if the timestamp field is called `timestamp`, to query the last 15
minutes of data:
[source,esql]
----
FROM kibana_sample_data_logs
| WHERE timestamp > NOW() - 15minutes
----","new_string":"[discrete]
[[esql-kibana-time-filter]]
=== Time filtering

To display data within a specified time range, use the
{kibana-ref}/set-time-filter.html[time filter]. The time filter is only enabled
when the indices you're querying have a field called `@timestamp`.

[discrete]
[[esql-kibana-time-filter-params]]
==== Using the Kibana time filter

When you select a time range in Kibana's time filter, Kibana automatically
applies the filter to your {esql} query by adding two named parameters:
`?_tstart` and `?_tend`. These parameters represent the start and end of the
selected time range.

You can reference these parameters in your query using the <<esql-where>>
command. For example:

[source,esql]
----
FROM kibana_sample_data_logs
| WHERE @timestamp >= ?_tstart AND @timestamp < ?_tend
----

This is useful when you want to:

* Apply additional time-based filters beyond the standard time filter
* Use the time filter values in calculations or aggregations
* Filter on the `@timestamp` field in combination with other conditions

[discrete]
[[esql-kibana-time-filter-custom]]
==== Custom time filtering

If your indices do not have a timestamp field called `@timestamp`, you can use
the `?_tstart` and `?_tend` parameters with your custom timestamp field:

[source,esql]
----
FROM kibana_sample_data_logs
| WHERE timestamp >= ?_tstart AND timestamp < ?_tend
----

Alternatively, you can limit the time range using the <<esql-where>> command and
the <<esql-now>> function. For example, to query the last 15 minutes of data:

[source,esql]
----
FROM kibana_sample_data_logs
| WHERE timestamp > NOW() - 15minutes
----

You can also use the `?_tstart` and `?_tend` parameters with the <<esql-bucket>>
function to create time buckets that align with the selected time range:

[source,esql]
----
FROM kibana_sample_data_logs
| WHERE @timestamp >= ?_tstart AND @timestamp < ?_tend
| STATS count = COUNT(*) BY bucket = BUCKET(@timestamp, 50, ?_tstart, ?_tend)
----

This creates 50 auto-incrementing time buckets spanning the selected time range."}}],"stop_reason":null,"stop_sequence":null,"usage":{"input_tokens":4,"cache_creation_input_tokens":232,"cache_read_input_tokens":32978,"cache_creation":{"ephemeral_5m_input_tokens":232,"ephemeral_1h_input_tokens":0},"output_tokens":1,"service_tier":"standard"}},"parent_tool_use_id":null,"session_id":"7c90dd25-ecac-479f-a611-964de795cd83","uuid":"71ac4c5b-529d-4fed-b9c1-e2027b9ea67d"}

{"type":"user","message":{"role":"user","content":[{"tool_use_id":"toolu_01MMR3qwbJAkGUrCevnTNgqA","type":"tool_result","content":"   170→[discrete]
   171→[[esql-kibana-time-filter]]
   172→=== Time filtering
   173→
   174→To display data within a specified time range, use the
   175→{kibana-ref}/set-time-filter.html[time filter]. The time filter is only enabled
   176→when the indices you're querying have a field called `@timestamp`.
   177→
   178→[discrete]
   179→[[esql-kibana-time-filter-params]]
   180→==== Using the Kibana time filter
   181→
   182→When you select a time range in Kibana's time filter, Kibana automatically
   183→applies the filter to your {esql} query by adding two named parameters:
   184→`?_tstart` and `?_tend`. These parameters represent the start and end of the
   185→selected time range.
   186→
   187→You can reference these parameters in your query using the <<esql-where>>
   188→command. For example:
   189→
   190→[source,esql]
   191→----
   192→FROM kibana_sample_data_logs
   193→| WHERE @timestamp >= ?_tstart AND @timestamp < ?_tend
   194→----
   195→
   196→This is useful when you want to:
   197→
   198→* Apply additional time-based filters beyond the standard time filter
   199→* Use the time filter values in calculations or aggregations
   200→* Filter on the `@timestamp` field in combination with other conditions
   201→
   202→[discrete]
   203→[[esql-kibana-time-filter-custom]]
   204→==== Custom time filtering
   205→
   206→If your indices do not have a timestamp field called `@timestamp`, you can use
   207→the `?_tstart` and `?_tend` parameters with your custom timestamp field:
   208→
   209→[source,esql]
   210→----
   211→FROM kibana_sample_data_logs
   212→| WHERE timestamp >= ?_tstart AND timestamp < ?_tend
   213→----
   214→
   215→Alternatively, you can limit the time range using the <<esql-where>> command and
   216→the <<esql-now>> function. For example, to query the last 15 minutes of data:
   217→
   218→[source,esql]
   219→----
   220→FROM kibana_sample_data_logs
   221→| WHERE timestamp > NOW() - 15minutes
   222→----
   223→
   224→You can also use the `?_tstart` and `?_tend` parameters with the <<esql-bucket>>
   225→function to create time buckets that align with the selected time range:
   226→
   227→[source,esql]
   228→----
   229→FROM kibana_sample_data_logs
   230→| WHERE @timestamp >= ?_tstart AND @timestamp < ?_tend
   231→| STATS count = COUNT(*) BY bucket = BUCKET(@timestamp, 50, ?_tstart, ?_tend)
   232→----
   233→
   234→This creates 50 auto-incrementing time buckets spanning the selected time range.
   235→
   236→[discrete]
   237→[[esql-kibana-visualizations]]
   238→=== Analyze and visualize data
   239→

## Summary of Changes

I updated the **Time filtering** section in `/docs/reference/esql/esql-kibana.asciidoc` (lines 171-234) to add comprehensive documentation for the `?_tstart` and `?_tend` parameters.

### What was added:

1. **New subsection: "Using the Kibana time filter"** (lines 179-200)
   - Explains that Kibana automatically adds `?_tstart` and `?_tend` named parameters when you select a time range
   - Provides an example of how to use these parameters in a WHERE clause
   - Lists use cases: additional time-based filters, calculations/aggregations, and combining with other conditions

2. **New subsection: "Custom time filtering"** (lines 202-234)
   - Shows how to use `?_tstart` and `?_tend` with custom timestamp fields (not `@timestamp`)
   - Retains the existing `NOW()` function example as an alternative
   - **Added BUCKET example**: Demonstrates using `?_tstart` and `?_tend` with the BUCKET function to create auto-incrementing time buckets aligned with the selected time range

### Structure:

The documentation now follows a logical flow:
- Introduction to time filtering
- How to use the Kibana time filter parameters (`?_tstart` and `?_tend`)
- Custom time filtering options (including the BUCKET example for auto-incrementing time buckets)
